message.content: Why is female circumcision so much more frowned upon than male circumcision ? . Explain like I'm five.

response:
Female circumcision, also known as female genital mutilation or cutting, is a practice that involves cutting or removing part of a girl or woman's genitalia, specifically the clitoris and/or the labia. This practice is typically performed without the person's consent and is done for cultural or religious reasons. It is often considered to be a harmful traditional practice and is illegal in many countries.

Male circumcision is the surgical removal of the foreskin, a fold of skin that covers the tip of the penis. It is a common practice in many parts of the world and is often done for cultural or religious reasons. Some people believe that male circumcision has health benefits, such as reducing the risk of certain infections and improving hygiene. However, there is ongoing debate about whether the benefits of male circumcision outweigh the risks.

Female circumcision is generally considered to be much more harmful and extreme than male circumcision. It is often performed without anesthesia and can cause serious physical complications, such as infection, bleeding, and difficulty urinating. It can also have psychological effects, such as depression, anxiety, and difficulty bonding with sexual partners.

In contrast, male circumcision is typically performed with anesthesia and has fewer risks and complications. While there are some risks and potential downsides to male circumcision, it is generally not considered to be as harmful as female circumcision.

Overall, female circumcision is more frowned upon because it is a more extreme and harmful practice that can have serious physical and psychological consequences. It is also often done without the person's consent, which is considered to be a violation of their rights.

message.content: When I calculate “internal rate of return (IRR)”, should I include cash balance?

response: Internal rate of return (IRR) is a measure of an investment's profitability. It represents the discount rate that makes the net present value (NPV) of an investment equal to zero. When calculating the IRR, you should include any cash flows associated with the investment, including cash balances. This means that if you have a positive cash balance at a particular point in time, you should include it as a positive cash flow in your IRR calculation. On the other hand, if you have a negative cash balance, you should include it as a negative cash flow.It's important to note that the IRR calculation assumes that any cash flows are reinvested at the IRR, so the inclusion of a cash balance in the calculation may affect the resulting IRR.

message.content: Buy car vs lease vs long term rent for 10 years period

response: There are several factors to consider when deciding whether to buy a car, lease a car, or rent a car on a long-term basis. Here are a few things to consider:Cost: Buying a car is typically the most expensive option upfront, as you will need to pay the full price of the vehicle. Leasing a car is generally less expensive upfront, as you will only need to pay for the depreciation of the vehicle during the lease term. Renting a car on a long-term basis can also be less expensive upfront, as you will only need to pay for the rental period.Flexibility: If you buy a car, you have the freedom to use it as you see fit and keep it for as long as you want. If you lease a car, you will have to return it at the end of the lease term. Renting a car on a long-term basis gives you more flexibility than leasing, as you can return the car at any time, but you will not have the same level of flexibility as if you owned the car.Maintenance: When you buy a car, you are responsible for all maintenance and repairs. When you lease a car, the dealership or leasing company is generally responsible for maintenance and repairs. When you rent a car on a long-term basis, the rental company is generally responsible for maintenance and repairs.Credit score: If you have a good credit score, you may be able to get a lower interest rate on a car loan, which can make buying a car more affordable. Leasing a car may also be more affordable if you have a good credit score, as you may be able to qualify for lower monthly payments. Renting a car on a long-term basis may not be affected by your credit score.Ultimately, the best option for you will depend on your specific financial situation, driving needs, and personal preferences.

message.content: why do some antennas such as the kind for TV have such a rail - like design ? Such as [ this one ] ( URL_0 ) . Please explain like I'm five.

response: The series of parallel elements are called directors , and they , in effect , focus the signal . A simple wire , sticking up , will have a sensitivity pattern which is circular with is centre around the wire , but this is n't much use for receiving faint signals and shutting out interfering signals . The [ Yagi - Uda antenna ] ( URL_0 ) uses the row of directors to stretch the sensitivity in the direction of the directors - that is , along the line of the " rail " of the antenna . This allows it to collect faint signals from ( nearly ) a single direction . The gains can be quite startling , but adding extra elements has increasingly little effect , so you do n't often see ridiculously long versions .

message.content: How can I spend less?

response: There are many tactics you can use.  If your biggest problem is regretting your larger purchases, I'd suggest giving yourself rules before making any purchases over a certain minimum dollar amount that you set for yourself.  For example, if that amount is $50 for an item, then any item starting at an average price of $51 would be subject to these rules. One of your long-term goals ought to be to become the kind of person who finds joy in saving money rather than spending it.  Make friends with frugal people - look for those who prefer games nights and potlucks to nights out at the club buying expensive drinks and dinners at the newest steak joint in town.  Learn the thrill of a deal, but even more learn the thrill of your savings growing.  You don't want to enjoy money in the bank for the purposes of becoming a miser.  Instead you want to realize that money in the bank helps you achieve your goals — buying the house you want, donating a significant amount of money to a cause you ardently support, allowing you to take a dream vacation, letting you buy with cash the car you always wanted, the possibilities are endless.  As Dave Ramsey says, "Live like no one else, so you can live like no one else."

message.content: How to rebalance a portfolio without moving money into losing investments

response: There are several ways to rebalance a portfolio without moving money into losing investments:Sell winning investments and use the proceeds to buy more of the underperforming investments. This can help bring the overall allocation of the portfolio back in line with the original investment plan.Use new money that is added to the portfolio to buy more of the underperforming investments. For example, if you are adding money to the portfolio through regular investments or contributions, you can use that money to buy more of the underperforming investments to help bring the overall allocation back in line with the original investment plan.Hold off on rebalancing until the underperforming investments start to recover. If you don't have any new money to invest and you don't want to sell your winning investments, you can wait until the underperforming investments start to recover before rebalancing the portfolio. This can help avoid the issue of selling investments that are still losing money.Use exchange-traded funds (ETFs) or mutual funds to rebalance the portfolio. These types of investment vehicles allow you to buy or sell a basket of stocks or other securities in a single transaction, which can be a more efficient way to rebalance the portfolio without having to sell individual investments.Overall, the key is to have a plan in place for rebalancing your portfolio and to stick to that plan, even if it means holding off on rebalancing until the underperforming investments start to recover.

message.content: How are passwords cracked ? You always see websites tell you to create strong passwords because simple passwords can be cracked . How ? Explain like I'm five.

response: There are many ways that passwords can be cracked. One way is through the use of a "brute force" attack, where a computer program tries every possible combination of letters, numbers, and symbols until it finds the correct one. This can be time-consuming, but with the use of powerful computers, it is possible to crack even very strong passwords. Another way to crack passwords is through the use of "dictionary attacks," where the program uses a list of common words and phrases to try and guess the password. This method can be faster than a brute force attack, but it is also less likely to be successful because it only tries common words and phrases. Finally, passwords can also be stolen by hackers who use various tricks to trick people into revealing their passwords, or by taking advantage of vulnerabilities in websites or apps to gain access to password databases. To create a strong password, it is important to use a combination of upper and lower case letters, numbers, and symbols, and to make the password long enough that it would be difficult to guess or crack. It is also a good idea to use different passwords for different websites and to change your passwords regularly to keep them secure.

message.content: How can some things like Gay marriage and Marijuana be legal in some states and not all ? Canadian that is curious Please explain like I'm five.

message.content: inflation Why does it happen ? Is it inevitable ? Why ? Is there a conceivable economic system in which currency values are stagnant ? Please explain like I'm five.

response: Inflation is the rise in the price of goods and services . Why does it happen ? There are many reasons . One is an increase in money supply . As a gov't prints more money , it 's value decreases because there is more of it . Another reason is consumer demand while maintaining scarcity . If the market wants to purchase 1000 widgets today and there are only 500 widgets available for purchase , the price will rise until the market says it only demands 500 widgets . It 's inevitable . Why ? It 's a result of any economy . Goods are being produced . Services are being rendered . Currency is being exchanged . But , it 's important when discussing economics to think about scale . In the short term prices rise as demand rises and/or money is printed . In the long term the market should adjust evening things out . For example , when DVD players first came out they were very expensive . There were n't many companies making them and DVD 's were expensive . As the market starting heating up ( more demand ) more and more companies started making DVD players . And they started making them more efficiently . So , supply started going up . DVD players were n't scarce anymore . I do n't think currency values could ever be stagnant . Currency is just a commodity . You exchange it for goods and services . The supply and demand of those good and services are in constant flux . Therefore the supply and demand of currency is in constant flux .

message.content: FICA was not withheld from my paycheck

response: According to this section in Publication 15:  Collecting underwithheld taxes from employees.   If you withheld no   income, social security, or Medicare taxes or less than the correct   amount from an employee's wages, you can make it up from later pay to   that employee. But you’re the one who owes the underpayment.   Reimbursement is a matter for settlement between you and the employee.   [...] it seems that if the employer withheld less than the correct amount of FICA taxes from you, it is still the employer who owes your FICA taxes to the government, not you. I do not believe there is a way for you, an employee (not self-employed), to directly pay FICA taxes to the government without going through the employer. The employer can deduct the underwithheld amount from you future paychecks (assuming you still work for them), or settle it with you in some other way. In other words, you owe the employer, and the employer owes the government, but you do not directly owe the government. If they do deduct it from your future pay, then they can issue a corrected W-2, to reflect the amount deducted from you. But they cannot issue a corrected W-2 that says FICA were deducted from you if it wasn't.

message.content: Will refinancing my auto loan hurt my mortgage approval or help it?

response: Generally it is not recommended that you do anything potentially short-term deleterious to your credit during the process of seeking a mortgage loan - such as opening a new account, closing old accounts, running up balances, or otherwise applying for any kind of loan (people often get carried away and apply for loans to cover furniture and appliances for the new home they haven't bought yet). You are usually OK to do things that have at least a short-term positive effect, like paying down debt. But refinancing - which would require applying for a non-home loan - is exactly the sort of hard-pull that can drop your credit rating. It is not generally advised. The exception to this is would be if you have an especially unusual situation with an existing loan (like your car), that is causing a deal-breaking situation with your home loan. This would for example be having a car payment so high that it violates maximum Debt-to-Income ratios (DTI). If your monthly debt payments are more than 43% of your monthly income, for instance, you will generally be unable to obtain a "qualified mortgage", and over 28-36% will disqualify you from some lenders and low-cost mortgage options. The reason this is unusual is that you would have to have a bizarrely terrible existing loan, which could somehow be refinanced without increasing your debt while simultaneously providing a monthly savings so dramatic that it would shift your DTI from "unacceptable" to "acceptable". It's possible, but most simple consumer loan refis just don't give that kind of savings. In most cases you should just "sit tight" and avoid any new loans or refinances while you seek a home purchase. If you want to be sure, you'll need to figure out your DTI ratio (which I recommend anyway) and see where you would be before and after a car refinance. If this would produce a big swing, maybe talk with some mortgage loan professionals who are familiar with lending criteria and ask for their opinion as to whether the change would be worth it. 9 times out of 10, you should wait until after your loan is closed and the home is yours before you try to refinance your car. However I would only warn you that if you think your house + car payment is too much for you to comfortably afford, I'd strongly recommend you seriously reconsider your budget, current car ownership, and house purchasing plans. You might find that after the house purchase the car refi isn't available either, or fine print means it wouldn't provide the savings you thought it would. Don't buy now hoping an uncertain cost-saving measure will work out later.

message.content: how do airline pilots predict turbulence ? So when I 'm flying the pilot often pops the seatbelt button on and advises were gon na have some rough air coming up . How do they know what the air is like before they 've flew into it ? Explain like I'm five.

response:
Airline pilots can predict turbulence by using a variety of tools and techniques. Here are a few ways they can do this:

Weather forecasts: Pilots can check weather forecasts and maps to see if there are any areas of stormy weather or strong winds that could cause turbulence.

Radar: Many planes are equipped with radar systems that can detect areas of turbulence ahead of the plane. The radar sends out a beam of energy and measures how it bounces back, which can help pilots see if there are any areas of rough air ahead.

Other pilots: Pilots can also communicate with other pilots who have recently flown through the same area to get reports on the conditions they experienced.

Experience: Pilots who have flown for a long time may have a good sense of what types of weather and conditions are likely to cause turbulence, based on their own past experiences.

Overall, pilots use a combination of these tools and techniques to try to predict and avoid turbulence as much as possible. However, it is important to note that turbulence is a natural occurrence and can sometimes be difficult to predict, especially if it is caused by rapidly changing weather conditions.

message.content: Should I consider my investment in a total stock market fund “diverse”?

response: Typically investing in only two securities is not a good idea when trying to spread risk. Even though you are in the VTI which is spread out over a large amount of securites it should in theory reduce portfolio beta to zero, or in this case as close to it as possible. The VTI however has a beta of 1.03 as of close today in New York. This means that the VTI moves roughly in exact tandem as "the market" usually benched against the S&P 500, so this means that the VTI is slightly more volatile than that index. In theory beta can be 0, this would be akin to investing in T-bills which are 'assumed' to be the risk free rate. So in theory it is possible to reduce the risk in your portfolio and apply a more capital protective model. I hope this helps you a bit.

message.content: what is "thin film" technology

response:
Thin film technology refers to the process of depositing a thin layer of material onto a substrate or base material. This thin layer can range from a few nanometers to a few micrometers in thickness, and is typically applied using techniques such as physical vapor deposition, chemical vapor deposition, or sputtering.

Thin films are used in a wide range of applications, including electronics, optics, energy storage, and sensors. In electronics, thin films are used to create thin film transistors (TFTs), which are used in LCD displays and other electronic devices. In optics, thin films are used to create coatings for lenses and other optical components to improve their performance. In energy storage, thin films are used to create thin film batteries and supercapacitors. In sensors, thin films are used to create thin film sensors that can detect various types of stimuli, such as temperature, pressure, and humidity.

There are several advantages to using thin film technology. Thin films can be applied to a wide range of materials, including metals, semiconductors, and insulators. They can also be applied to flexible and/or irregularly shaped substrates, which makes them useful for a variety of applications. In addition, thin films can be applied using relatively simple and low-cost processes, which makes them an attractive option for mass production.

message.content: what classes are considered humanities

Humanities are academic disciplines that study the human condition, using methods that are primarily analytical, critical, or speculative, as distinguished from the mainly empirical approaches of the natural sciences. The humanities include ancient and modern languages, literature, philosophy, history, archaeology, anthropology, human geography, law, politics, religion, and art.

Some common examples of classes that are considered to be in the humanities include:

Art history
Classics (e.g., ancient Greek and Roman culture, language, and literature)
Communication

History
Languages (e.g., Spanish, French, German, Chinese)
Linguistics
Music
Philosophy
Religious studies
Theatre
It is worth noting that the boundaries between the humanities and other academic disciplines are not always clear, and there is some overlap with fields such as sociology, psychology, and anthropology.

message.content: Please explain what is "Competitive learning"

response:
Competitive learning is a form of unsupervised learning in artificial neural networks, in which nodes compete for the right to respond to a subset of the input data. A variant of Hebbian learning, competitive learning works by increasing the specialization of each node in the network.  It is well suited to finding clusters within data.
Models and algorithms based on the principle of competitive learning include vector quantization and self-organizing maps (Kohonen maps).

response: Imagine you had a business selling lollipops at school . Since you can buy a bag of 100 for $ 10 , you can sell them for 25¢ a piece for a profit . But you do n't have $ 10 . Everybody makes $ 2 from their $ 1 investment - everybody wins . you could pay them back their $ 1 investment and another $ 1 profit - this extra is called a * * dividend * * . Now , would your investors go in again next week ? Sure ! You 're doubling their money . And you ran out of lollipops right ? So maybe get everyone together to vote and we all agree at a * * shareholder meeting * * to skip the dividend and turn the venture into a * * business * * that reinvests the profit into 2 bags of lollipops and make money even faster . Next week you sell out again . Since you 're just one sales guy , you still only cost $ 5 and your * * profit margin * * has risen . You can now buy 4.5 bags of lollipops each week . Your business is growing ! Now the new kid in school has noticed your business and he wants to buy a share . You * * sold * * a share to your friends for $ 1 . But now each week , thay share grew in the potential value of its dividend . So how much should a share cost today ? Even though the investors have n't actually gotten money back on the business , the share they own has grown in value as the business has grown . Well one of your old friends wants to buy a comic book that costs $ 5 and he has no allowance because he spent all his money buying his share the first week . He 's ready to start making money back but the stockholders want to keep reinvesting the dividends . So some of the shareholders and the new kid , Martin get together on the playground and start talking . Comic book kid says is willing to sell his share . So he * * asks * * for $ 5 from Martin . But Martin does n't want to pay that . So Martin * * bids * * $ 4.50 . There is now a * * bid - ask spread of .50¢ * * - meaning it 's less likely for a sale to happen then if that spread was $ 0 and more likely than if the spread was $ 1 . The stock might not actually sell today because the market is slow and sticky rather than * * liquid * * . The stock in the company is * * illiquid * * . Some more kids gather around . They 're hip . They want to grow their lunch money . So they * * bid * * $ 4.75.,$4.85 , $ 4.95 - * * sold * * comic book kid thinks this is close enough and a transaction happens . The market is gaining * * liquidity * * as more buyers and sellers gain interest . But now Martin 's got hella - bad FOMO ( fear of missing out ) . He offers $ 5.10 to buy it from the new owner . Seeing the * * stock price * * rise , other owners consider selling . They consider * * holding * * . They consider buying more . All start negotiating . Some kids call their parents and ask for an advance on their allowance . Some parent hear about this crazy business that doubles each week and they tell the kid to act as a * * broker * * on the trading floor and do the deal on the parent 's behalf . Baby , you 've got yourself a stock pit . # # Waaaaaaahhhh ! ! ! Okay , okay Part II * * Market , Limit , Stop orders ; Futures contracts ; Options ; Shorting ; Insider trading , and market manipulation * * None of this stuff affects the * * profit * * of the company . The stock was sold in the * * initial public ( school ) offering * * ( IPO ) . And since then , the company itself has just sold lollipops and reinvested in growth . But if they want to grow more they can get all the shareholders together and vote to sell more shares . And neighborhood adults and local business owners want to grow their money . So they head over to the playground and ask the teachers if they can get in to buy some stock . The teacher are like , " Um ... no you ca n't go on the playground , you do n't go to this school and you 're an adult , perv . So the local adults pass notes to the kids to buy stock on their behalf and have the kids * * broker * * a deal . But the price different people will sell for keeps moving so the kid asks , " what price are you willing to buy it at ? " And the parent ( client ) can say : - place a * * limit order * * - I 'll only pay up to $ 6.50 and if it moves past that before you can find a seller , cancel it - place a * * market order * * - I 'll buy it at any price you can get it for over the next hour or so . - place a * * stop order * * - for some reason I only want to buy above a certain price . Probably because if it is moving down in price I think it will keep moving down . These purchases are getting complicated and kids do n't want to work for free . Adults ( institutional investors ) have * a lot * of money compared to kids . Each aggressive purchase makes the stock price move up . The broker kids get paid a fee - maybe 25¢. But the adults are buying like $ 1000 in stock at a time . So a really clever kid , Max , decides to start buying LOLI when his adult does . Since the stock price was like $ 7 , if an adult wants to buy 1000 shares , the price has to move up as he asks kid after kid after kid to sell all his shares . He knows this means the stock price will get higher and higher - so he personally buys as much as he can before he starts trading for his adult . He has invented * * frontrunning * * . Teachers see this and get upset because frontrunning drives the price of the stock up for neighborhood adults unfairly and those adults are the tax payers that pay the teacher 's salary . So they declare frontrunning against the rules . Meanwhile , as the CEO and sole employee ( I guess ) of Lollico . you know the weekly sales figures before anyone else . You could * * manipulate * * the market price by leaking information about it . You can say the sales are low , then buy up stock and say - " psych " ( do kids still say psych ? ) and watch the price rise . Teachers hate this too because again it makes the taxpaying adults mad . So they say its against the rules and call it * * market manipulation * * - specifically it is * * misreporting financials * * and * * insider trading * * . The opposite is * * pump and dump * * . So now you need to file a record of your sales and expenses with the Special Educational Council or * * SEC * * ( securities and exchange commission - a stock is also called a security for some reason ) that ensures everybody is following the rules . Max - recently released from timeout - has another brilliant idea . LOLI is now at $ 4,555 because of all the adults who have bought in . So Max , while he does n't own the stock , has borrowed it from an adult ( as a loan for a small interest rate called * * security lending * * ) and sold it for less ( * * short * * ) than what it might be worth at the immediate current price . If the price moves up , he will owe a lot of money to those adults in order to buy back the stock at a higher price . Potentially infinite money if the price keeps climbing and he ca n't buy it . message.content: Please explain what is "False negative rate"

response:
A false positive is an error in binary classification in which a test result incorrectly indicates the presence of a condition (such as a disease when the disease is not present), while a false negative is the opposite error, where the test result incorrectly indicates the absence of a condition when it is actually present. These are the two kinds of errors in a binary test, in contrast to the two kinds of correct result (a true positive and a true negative). They are also known in medicine as a false positive (or false negative) diagnosis, and in statistical classification as a false positive (or false negative) error.
In statistical hypothesis testing the analogous concepts are known as type I and type II errors, where a positive result corresponds to rejecting the null hypothesis, and a negative result corresponds to not rejecting the null hypothesis. The terms are often used interchangeably, but there are differences in detail and interpretation due to the differences between medical testing and statistical hypothesis testing.

message.content: Why do planes need such high altitude why ca nt they complete their whole trip 200 meters in the air ? Please explain like I'm five.

response: There are a few reasons why planes fly at high altitudes: 1. Lower air resistance: The air at high altitudes is less dense, which means there is less resistance for the plane to fly through. This makes it easier for the plane to move forward, and it can save fuel by not having to use as much power to overcome air resistance. 2. Fewer obstacles: There are fewer obstacles (like tall buildings and mountains) at high altitudes, which makes it easier for the plane to navigate its way to its destination. 3. Better weather: High altitudes tend to have more stable weather, with fewer clouds and less turbulence. This makes for a smoother and safer flight for the passengers. 4. Efficiency: Flying at high altitudes also allows planes to take advantage of the jet stream, which is a high-speed wind that blows from west to east. This can help the plane travel faster and use less fuel. Overall, flying at high altitudes helps planes to be more efficient, safer, and comfortable for passengers. However, it's important to note that planes do not always fly at the highest possible altitudes, and they may fly at lower altitudes for various reasons (e.g., during takeoff and landing, or when flying over mountainous terrain).

Metastasis is when distant tissues can be infected by , for example , crossing into the blood stream via the lymph nodes . There they can spread to dangerous area like the liver or the brain . Once they get to these new locations they continue to grow , crowding out the normal cells that should be growing there , and causing organs to fail .

message.content: What are birthmarks ? I have a baby brother who was born five weeks ago now and he has a small birthmark on his head and that got me wondering what birthmarks are . Please explain like I'm five.

response:
Birthmarks are spots on the skin that are present at birth or appear shortly after birth. They are very common and can appear anywhere on the body. Some birthmarks are red or pink, while others are brown or black. They can be flat or raised, and some are smooth while others are bumpy. 
There are two main types of birthmarks: vascular birthmarks and pigmented birthmarks. Vascular birthmarks are caused by abnormal blood vessels in the skin, and they can be red, pink, or purple. Pigmented birthmarks are caused by an excess of pigment in the skin, and they can be brown or black. 
Birthmarks are usually harmless and don't cause any problems. Some people choose to have them removed for cosmetic reasons, but this is not necessary. Most birthmarks fade or disappear on their own over time.

message.content: What causes left sided chest pain?i am 17 years old,5ft3 and weigh 9st10,lately i have been getting pains in my chest and the left side of my body when i take breathe it feels like im breathless,i got pain on the left side of my back just behind my heart... today i got an unusual pain were the whole of my left side from my heart to the bottom of my left rib felt like it has a stitch

response:
Chest pain can be caused by a variety of conditions, some of which can be serious. It's important to get a proper evaluation by a healthcare professional if you are experiencing chest pain, particularly if it is accompanied by other symptoms such as shortness of breath, nausea, or sweating.

There are many possible causes of left-sided chest pain, including:

Musculoskeletal problems: Chest pain on the left side could be caused by muscle strain, a pinched nerve, or other musculoskeletal issues.

Heart problems: Chest pain on the left side could be a sign of a heart attack, angina (chest pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart), or other heart problems.

Lung problems: Chest pain on the left side could be caused by a lung infection, such as pneumonia, or by other lung problems such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Gastrointestinal problems: Chest pain on the left side could be caused by gastrointestinal issues such as acid reflux (heartburn) or a peptic ulcer.

Other causes: There are many other possible causes of left-sided chest pain, including an injury to the chest, a blood clot in the lung (pulmonary embolism), and even anxiety or stress.

It's important to see a healthcare professional for an evaluation if you are experiencing chest pain, particularly if it is accompanied by other symptoms or if it is severe or persistent. They will be able to determine the cause of your symptoms and recommend the appropriate treatment.

message.content: Carburetors . How do they work ? What is jetting ? What / How synch ? Idle synch ? Explain like I'm five.

response:
A carburetor is a device that mixes fuel and air in the right proportions and delivers the mixture to the engine of a vehicle. It's kind of like a blender for fuel and air! The carburetor has a few different parts that work together to mix the fuel and air and deliver it to the engine.

One important part is the float bowl. This is a small reservoir of fuel that sits inside the carburetor. The float bowl has a float that rises and falls with the level of the fuel in the bowl. When the fuel level gets low, the float drops and opens a valve to let more fuel in.

Another important part is the jet. The jet is a small opening that controls the flow of fuel into the carburetor. The size of the jet determines how much fuel flows into the carburetor. If the jet is too small, there won't be enough fuel flowing into the carburetor and the engine won't run well. If the jet is too large, there will be too much fuel flowing into the carburetor and the engine will run too rich (meaning there's too much fuel and not enough air).

Jetting is the process of adjusting the size of the jet in the carburetor to get the right mix of fuel and air for the engine. This is usually done by changing the size of the jet or by using different jets with different size openings.

Synchronizing carburetors is the process of making sure that the carburetors on a multi-carbureted engine are all delivering the same amount of fuel and air to each cylinder. This is important because if one carburetor is delivering more fuel and air than the others, it can cause the engine to run poorly.

Idle synchronization is the process of making sure that the carburetors are delivering the right mix of fuel and air at idle speed (when the engine is running at a low speed). This is important because if the carburetors are not properly synchronized at idle, the engine may run poorly or stall.

Overall, the frequency of referendums varies from country to country and depends on the specific political system in place. In some countries, referendums may be held more frequently than in others.

message.content: Why do we root for fictional anti - heroes and criminals but are horrified by real ones ? Why do we cheer on people like Dexter , when if he were real we would be appalled ? Please explain like I'm five.

response: Well - written fiction puts us into the frame of mind of the protagonist . It shows us the world from their point of view , and draws us into it . From a neutral , third party standpoint , antiheroes and criminals are awful people who need to be stopped . But from their own perspective , they 're just doing what they need to do . In good fiction , we see things their way , but an argument can be made for the reverse . Here 's an example of what I mean . Suppose that there was a terrorist , someone who bombs government buildings , attacks security guards , and disappears without a trace . Imagine if suddenly , that person gained super powers , and pledged to transport the human race from this world into an apocalyptic hellscape of war and survival . That person is Neo . From our perspective , the Matrix is like 1000 times better , but from his it has to end . The movies draw us into his perception , but a neutral third party would disagree . That 's part of what makes the movie great - it forces us to imagine and identify with a truly alien proposition .

message.content: Evolution . I 've gotten the " Why are n't monkeys evolving right now speech ? " Just wanting to know some more background that I may not already know . Explain like I'm five.

response: Every living thing is always evolving . Monkeys are evolving right now , us people are evolving right now , and even single - cell organisms are evolving right now . The problem with the question " why are n't monkeys evolving right now ? " is that the people asking it are making some dramatically false assumptions about evolution . These people are assuming that evolution is a change they 'll be able to see happening right in front of them . Evolution is n't a transformation like a caterpillar to a butterfly , it does n't happen overnight , or in a lifetime , or even in multiple lifetimes . It is a process that can take millions of years to play out . Although in some cases we * can * see it happening faster . Species that reproduce faster , such as some viruses and bacteria , can evolve at a much faster rate . This is why doctors are often hesitant to prescribe antibiotic drugs , and [ will tell you not to take antibiotic drugs when you have a cold ] ( URL_0 ) ( which is caused by viruses , which antibiotics have no effect on ) - bacteria can evolve to build up a resistance to such treatments if they are used too liberally . To give you an idea of how it works , let 's start with common , everyday stuff . You are a product of your parents ' combined DNA ( the " blueprints of life " that say how you 're built ) . If your mom is black and your dad is white , odds are your skin color will be somewhere in - between . If your parents and grandparents all had curly hair or big noses , it 's very likely you will too . If your parents and grandparents all got cancer , there 's a very strong chance you 'll get it too . This is because when your DNA blueprint is created , it 's mostly just a combination of the DNA blueprints of your parents . Half from your father , and half from your mother . However , every now and then , something randomly changes . You get a little line on the blueprint that did n't come from your mother or your father . Consider it a smudge on the copying machine used to make that blueprint , and even though it was n't in your parents ' plans , it 's a part of your plans now . This is called a " mutation " . Probably gets you thinking of the Ninja Turtles and the X - Men , right ? Well , most mutations are n't anything even remotely like that . In fact , most mutations do absolutely nothing at all . Your DNA blueprints are so incredibly huge that , for the most part , one tiny little line out of place here or there is n't going to make any noticeable change . Just a little quirk on your blueprint , albeit a little quirk that you might pass on when you make a copy of the blueprint ( when you have kids ) . Every now and then , one of those little lines out of place will show up somewhere where it * does * do something different , or maybe a few of those out - of - place lines build up and do something together that they did n't do before . This can be a good change or a bad change , or something inexplicable . It can be as simple as your skin color being a little lighter than usual , or grow hair on your elbows . It can be something that causes your brain to function wrong , or make you born with a hole in your heart . These are traits you did n't get from your mother and father , traits that make you slightly different , slightly * new * . And sometimes these things are good , and sometimes they 're bad . Bad stuff , like the " hole in the heart " example , or other traits that make them not as good at evading predators , or not as good at getting food , often leads to the creatures that have them dying without having children , so they do n't pass on those wonky blueprints to any future generations . Good traits , ones that make a living thing better at getting food , better at avoiding predators , or better at reproducing , result in that trait getting passed on to new generations . This is a process called Natural Selection . Nature constantly does this . Everything is always mutating , ever so slightly , and if a mutation is bad , it dies out , and if it 's good , it thrives and gets passed on to new generations . As time goes on , these good traits build up , and after many , many generations , lifeforms gradually become something different than they used to be . People have used this to our advantage even before we knew we were doing it . Domestication is a good example . At one point in time , some guy was undoubtedly hanging around the campfire when he saw something he 'd seen a hundred times before - some wolves scavenging around his campsite looking for food . However , he noticed something different with one of them . It was friendly . Maybe he took a liking to it , fed it scraps ... and suddenly , being a friendly wolf is a * very * successful survival trait . If you 're friendly to humans , you get fed ! Over time , more wolves start to evolve this behavioral trait , and more and more people started to notice that the wolves hanging around their campsite were n't mean and nasty , but were nice . Then , at some point some guy took one of those wolves and kept it around his house , and he paid attention when that wolf had pups , and noticed that some of the baby wolves it had were more friendly than others . Well , that person probably got rid of the less friendly ones , and continued to breed the friendly ones ... until , after a while of doing this , they were all even more friendly . This process was undoubtedly repeated numerous times . Maybe at one point one of the babies looked a bit different , had more fur or was a bit smaller , and it would be pulled aside and bred until they could make all of them like that . This is a bit of a simplification , but imagine this process going on over many thousands of years ... and eventually you 've gone from a world with nothing but wild , feral wolves , to a world with numerous varieties of domesticated dogs . The process of evolution , as you see it in cartoons and stuff , generally shows a microscopic organism morphing into a fish , which grows legs and becomes a lizard crawling on land , which grows fur and becomes a monkey , which stands up and becomes a caveman , who sheds his hair and becomes a modern man . This kinda ' conveys the idea , but it is such an oversimplification it has undoubtedly led to much confusion that has caused a lot of the misunderstanding behind it . To turn that process into something more closely resembling reality , first you 'd have to stretch it over * millions * of years . Second , you 'd be showing the change not by one creature morphing into another , then another , and so on , but by each creature giving birth to creatures * slightly * different than it is . Thirdly , each creature gives birth to * multiple * creatures . Some are more or less the same , some have good new features and thrive , some have bad new features and die off ( picture an ever - expanding tree , with some branches ending sooner than others ) . This tree , now that you look at it , is huge . If you go up close and look at any one part of it , you wo n't really see much change - each generation more or less looks just like the previous one . But the farther you zoom out , the more you 'll see more dramatic change . Follow back humanity far enough and you 'll see that both humans and monkeys branch off from the same common ancestor . One group of us became humans , the other became monkeys , even though at the time , we seemed nearly identical . But gradually , we grew apart , became different , even though each generation was mostly just like the one that came before . Follow that same path back further still , and you 'll see simpler and simpler life - forms . Eventually , you see that all mammals have a common origin , just like monkeys and humans share a common origin . Rats did n't turn into monkeys , but both rats and monkeys have the same ancestor , millions of years ago . You 'll also notice that a few species have n't changed much , even in those millions of years . Sharks , alligators and cockroaches , for example , are believed to be more or less just like they were many millions of years ago ( modern humans , by comparison , are believed to be only about 200,000 years old ) . These creatures did n't stop evolving - undoubtedly they still mutate and have variations , but since those species as we know them have apparently remained successful in their environments , despite the changes those environments have gone through over the ages , those species have continued to thrive in their current form , perhaps with occasional genetic offspring branching off to become a new species in its own right - mantises and termites , for example , are believed to have branched off from early cockroaches . Again , this is n't to say that at some point a cockroach had a termite baby , but that at some point a cockroach had a cockroach baby that was a little different , and that one had a baby that was a little different , and so on , until eventually the differences added up to be a completely different sort of animal , a new species . That 's evolution at work .

message.content: Why ESR increased after having antibiotics for suspected infection?I am 45 years old with controlled type 2 diabetes ,  pco, pain in  left top side of my  back. I have been having  severe headaches. My  esr  increased from  35 t0 55 even when i had taken 250 mg proximexa  as advised by my doctor since he suspected infection. why did my esr increase after 3 days of antibiotics?

response: ESR is a nonspecific test indicating the presence of an inflammatory condition. This could be due to an infection or to many other causes. The inflammatory process and the change in ESR could be due to the infection and would occur regardless of antibiotic treatment- it is part of the body's response to the infection. If the infection clears up with treatment, the inflammatory process will start to clear up, but signs of it such as the ESR may take some time to return to normal. The ESR is not useful for following the course of an infection. Again, it may also be due to an entirely different condition from the infection, such as arthritis, lupus, response to injuries, etc etc. Hope this helps.

message.content: Can computer hackers wander around your desktop ? Is it mostly just hijacking web browsers and logging keystrokes , or can hackers gain control of your computer and click open files on your hard drive folders at will ? How does hacking work ? Please explain like I'm five.

response: Hacking is a broad term that can refer to many different activities, some of which involve gaining unauthorized access to computer systems or networks. There are many ways that hackers can try to gain access to a computer or network, and they can use a variety of techniques to do so. One way that hackers might try to gain access to a computer is by finding vulnerabilities in the system and exploiting them. For example, a hacker might try to find a way to get into a computer by guessing the password or by finding a way to bypass security measures. Another way that hackers might try to gain access to a computer is by sending a virus or malware through email or by visiting a website that has been compromised. When a person clicks on a link or opens an attachment, the virus or malware can be installed on the person's computer, allowing the hacker to gain access. Overall, hacking can be a serious threat to computer security, and it is important to take steps to protect your computer and your personal information. This can include using strong passwords, keeping your software and operating system up to date, and being cautious when clicking on links or downloading attachments.

message.content: why viruses are n't alive Something I learned in life science a while ago but never really understand . They seem to show attributes of living things but are n't technically alive ? What ? ? Explain like I'm five.

message.content: How can my computer be in hybernation mode when not charged ? ( my battery has died ) Edit : I had an discussion with my father and guys won this one for me ! Danke Explain like I'm five.

response:
Hibernation mode is a power-saving state that allows a computer to quickly resume from where it left off by saving its current state to the hard drive. It is typically used when a computer is going to be inactive for an extended period of time, such as when it is turned off or put into sleep mode.

A computer can't enter hibernation mode if the battery is dead, because it needs power to save the current state to the hard drive. When a computer is in hibernation mode, it uses very little power, so it can be left in this state for a long time without using up the battery. However, if the battery is dead, the computer won't be able to save its current state or stay in hibernation mode, and it will need to be turned off or plugged in to a power source before it can be used again.

In short, a computer can't be in hibernation mode when the battery is dead because it needs power to save its current state and stay in hibernation mode.

message.content: Where should I park my rainy-day / emergency fund?

response: It is generally recommended to keep your rainy-day or emergency fund in a safe and easily accessible place, such as a savings account or a short-term certificate of deposit (CD) at a bank or credit union. These types of accounts typically offer relatively low returns but also have little to no risk of losing your principal investment.Keep in mind that the primary purpose of an emergency fund is to provide a financial cushion in case of unexpected expenses or income disruptions, such as a job loss or medical emergency. As a result, it is important to prioritize safety and accessibility over potential returns when choosing where to park your emergency fund.Here are a few things to consider when selecting a place to keep your emergency fund:Safety: Look for accounts that are FDIC-insured or backed by the National Credit Union Administration (NCUA) to protect your money in the event that the institution goes out of business.Accessibility: Choose an account that allows you to easily withdraw your money when you need it, such as a savings account or short-term CD. Avoid investing your emergency fund in longer-term investments, such as stocks or mutual funds, as these may not be easily accessible in the event of an emergency.Fees: Look for accounts with low or no fees to maximize the returns on your emergency fund.Interest rates: While the primary purpose of an emergency fund is not to earn a high return, it is still a good idea to shop around and compare rates at different financial institutions to ensure you are getting the best return possible. Just keep in mind that the interest rate should not be the main factor in your decision, as the main goal is to keep your money safe and accessible.

message.content: Why is it considered necessary for a planet to have an atmosphere to sustain life ? Could n't life have evolved to survive without respiration ? Explain like I'm five.

response: An atmosphere is important for life on a planet because it helps to regulate the temperature and protect living things from harmful solar radiation. Without an atmosphere, the surface of a planet would be too hot during the day and too cold at night, which would make it difficult for life to survive. An atmosphere is also important because it provides the air that living things need to breathe. All living things need to exchange gases with their environment in order to survive. For example, humans and other animals need to breathe in oxygen and breathe out carbon dioxide. Plants, on the other hand, use a process called photosynthesis to take in carbon dioxide and produce oxygen. So, while it is possible that life could evolve to survive without an atmosphere or without the need to breathe, it is much more likely that life would evolve to take advantage of the benefits that an atmosphere provides.

message.content: If starfish do n't have brains , how do they have consciousness ? Is consciousness not dependent on the brain ? What is it then ? Please explain like I'm five.

response: Starfish, like all animals, have nervous systems that allow them to perceive their environment and respond to stimuli. However, they don't have brains in the way that humans do. Instead of a single central brain, they have a decentralized nervous system with a network of small ganglia (clusters of nerve cells) located throughout their body. This allows them to perform basic functions like moving, hunting for food, and avoiding predators.Consciousness is a complex and poorly understood phenomenon that is not fully understood by scientists. It is generally thought to be related to the brain and nervous system, but it is not fully dependent on them. Some scientists believe that consciousness arises from the interactions between different areas of the brain, while others think that it may be a fundamental aspect of the universe, like space or time. It is a topic of much debate and research in the fields of psychology, neuroscience, and philosophy.

message.content: What purpose did inventing a new language fulfil ? Why were so many languages invented if many of them were derived from existing ones ? Explain like I'm five.

response: Almost never does someone deliberately invent a new language . Language change slowly over time , and isolation allows them to diverge to the point where they are no longer mutually comprehensible . Sort of like speciation in biology . Bear in mind that until quite recently , almost nobody travelled . If a town 50 km away pronounced a word differently , most people in your town would never know about it . We 've gotten used to knowing how other dialects and accents sound , but that is a very recent development in the history of language . Incidentally , accent shifts are still happening . Canadian accents and American accents in the Great Lakes region are currently undergoing vowel shifts in opposite directions . If it were n't for easy travel and movies , etc , it 's entirely possible we 'd not be able to understand each other in 300 years ...

message.content: How can space and time bend ? It does n't make sense to me . I know in outer space you can travel in any direction but introduce the idea that same space can bend and overlap and I 'm lost . Explain like I'm five.

response: In physics, space and time are considered to be part of a single, unified concept called spacetime. According to the theory of relativity, the presence of mass or energy can cause spacetime to curve. This means that the straight path of a planet or spaceship, for example, may appear to bend as it travels through the curved spacetime around a massive object like a star or black hole. Imagine that spacetime is like a rubber sheet. If you place a heavy object on the sheet, it will cause the sheet to bend and curve. If you then roll a small ball on the sheet, it will follow the curve of the sheet rather than rolling in a straight line. This is similar to how the path of a planet or spaceship might appear to bend as it moves through the curved spacetime around a massive object. It's important to note that this is just an analogy and that the actual nature of spacetime is much more complex. However, it can help to provide a rough understanding of how mass and energy can affect the shape and structure of spacetime.

message.content: where does ground pepper come from

response: Ground black pepper is made from the dried, ground fruits of the pepper plant, which is native to India. The pepper plant, also known as Piper nigrum, is a woody, climbing vine that is grown in tropical regions around the world. The fruit of the pepper plant, known as the peppercorn, is harvested when it is ripe and then dried in the sun or by mechanical means. Once dried, the peppercorns are ground into a fine powder to produce ground black pepper. There are other types of pepper as well, such as white pepper and green pepper, which are made from different parts of the pepper plant and processed differently.

message.content: What are the tax implications if I do some work for a company for trade, rather than pay?

response: If you perform work for a company in exchange for goods or services rather than pay, it is considered bartering. The value of the goods or services that you receive in trade is taxable as income, and must be reported on your tax return.For example, if you perform $1,000 worth of work for a company in exchange for $1,000 worth of goods or services, you must report the value of the goods or services as income on your tax return.It's important to keep accurate records of the value of the goods or services that you receive in trade, as you may need to provide documentation to the IRS if you are audited. You should also be aware that you may be subject to self-employment taxes if you engage in a significant amount of bartering.If you have any specific questions about the tax implications of bartering, you should consult with a tax professional or the IRS.

message.content: If you shine a flashlight in someones eyes you can see pupil dilation happen very quickly . How come it takes so much longer for ' night vision ' to work effectively ? Night vision as in seeing things easily in the dark Please explain like I'm five.

response: The pupils are actually not very important in this because their size can only vary so much . The photoreceptors of the retina change in response to the light level , and that 's where most of the adjustability comes from . While the photopigments can be deactivated very quickly in response to bright light , if you then go back to a dark environment , the photopigments need to be regenerated , and that 's a slow process that can take up to 45 minutes . Simply put , in order to adjust to darkness , the eye needs to produce certain chemicals , and to adjust to bright light , it just needs to deactivate them . message.content: When a bank is robbed , do the people / companies get reimbursed by an insurance company or the bank for all of their money that has been lost ? Or is it not even their money in the bank ? Explain like I'm five.

response: It 's not their money in the bank . When you give your money to the bank , it 's just that : you 're giving it to them . What the bank does in return is give you a slip of paper otherwise known as a " balance " of how much money you have with them , that they need to be able to pay you should you request it back . As an added bonus : think about how a bank makes money , and incentivizes you , the customer to have them hold your money instead of another rival bank . The interest rate the bank advertises is the major selling point that most people would care about . How can they provide interest if your money just sits there ? It certainly does n't multiply on its own , otherwise under the mattress would be the ideal place to store it . Where the real money comes in is from loans . The bank uses all the money that people have given it , and attempt to make good investments on people applying for loans and earn additional income through interest they charge on top of those loans . A sound loan applicant with a well thought out business stratagem will most likely generate a return on the initial investment that the bank gave out , thus turning a profit and having more money than it had with everyone 's deposits . A lot of these happen every day and it 's why bankers look at " risk " which is between ' none ' ( a sound investment with no chance of losing money like an arbitrage ) and ' high ' ( an unwise investment unlikely to get any money back from , such as fedoras for dolphins ) The bank gives out this Return On Investment in very small amounts as a reward for using them across all the customers . And because you do n't own the money you gave them , just a balance that 's good for that much money from them they give you a little extra to incentivize your continued patronage .

message.content: Peer to Peer Lending Small notes Vs Large Notes

response: Peer-to-peer (P2P) lending is a type of financing that allows individuals to borrow and lend money directly to one another, without the involvement of traditional financial institutions like banks. In P2P lending, small notes refer to smaller loans that are typically made to individual borrowers, while large notes refer to larger loans that may be made to businesses or organizations.There are a few key differences between small notes and large notes in P2P lending:Borrower risk: Smaller loans, or small notes, may be considered less risky than larger loans because they are typically made to individual borrowers who are less likely to default on their loans. On the other hand, large notes may be considered more risky because they are often made to businesses or organizations, which may be more vulnerable to financial challenges.Loan terms: The terms of small notes and large notes may also differ. For example, small notes may have shorter repayment periods and lower interest rates, while large notes may have longer repayment periods and higher interest rates.Investment opportunities: Investors may have different preferences when it comes to investing in small notes versus large notes. Some investors may prefer the stability and lower risk of small notes, while others may be willing to take on more risk in exchange for the potential for higher returns from large notes.It's worth noting that P2P lending is a relatively new and rapidly evolving industry, and the specific terms and conditions of small notes and large notes may vary depending on the platform and the borrower's creditworthiness. It's always a good idea to thoroughly research and understand the terms of any investment before committing to it.

message.content: Suggest treatment for cramping pain in shoulder bladeHi I have strong cramping pain in the right shoulder blade region. It hurts to breathe deeply, cough and sneeze. Also the pain is intense if I move suddenly or the wrong way. I have had medical treatment with anti inflamitory and pain medication but this has not helped.

response:
I'm sorry to hear that you are experiencing pain in your shoulder blade. It's important to first determine the underlying cause of the cramping pain in order to determine the most appropriate treatment. There are several potential causes of shoulder blade pain, including muscle strain or spasm, pinched nerves, or problems with the spine or ribs.

Some potential treatment options for shoulder blade pain may include:

Rest and avoid activities that exacerbate the pain: This can help reduce inflammation and allow your body to heal.

Apply heat or cold: Applying heat or cold to the affected area can help reduce pain and inflammation. You can use a heating pad, hot water bottle, or warm shower to apply heat, or an ice pack or cold compress to apply cold.

Take over-the-counter pain medication: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen or naproxen can help reduce pain and inflammation.

Physical therapy: A physical therapist can help you stretch and strengthen the muscles in your shoulder blade and upper back to reduce pain and improve mobility.

Chiropractic care: A chiropractor can help realign the spine and address any misalignment or problems with the ribs that may be contributing to your shoulder blade pain.

Massage therapy: Massage can help relax tense muscles and improve circulation, which can reduce pain and improve mobility.

It's also important to see a healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. They may recommend further testing, such as X-rays or an MRI, to determine the cause of your shoulder blade pain and recommend additional treatment options if necessary.

message.content: Why does the water in the Carribean look clear and sometimes glow while water I m the gulf looks muddy and dark ? Is there like a particular plankton that does that blue glowing effect ? Please explain like I'm five.

response: Water clarity is mainly affected by two factors : ( 1 ) sediment floating around in the water and ( 2 ) plankton and other organic material . Like /u / jesonnier said , the Gulf is generally muddy from sediment from the Mississippi river . For the West Coast , it 's a combination of the two . Ocean surface water generally flows west to east due to the earth 's rotation . When deeper water flows in to replace the surface water that flowed out , it often brings more sediment with it that it picked up from the ocean floor . Thus , water near the surface on the West Coast has a fair amount of sediment in it that it loses as it moves further out east . The sediment also tends to be smaller than that in the water in the Caribbean , so it stays suspended near the surface more easily . The water near the West Coast is also more nutrient rich so there 's more plankton and other organic material . The Caribbean ( and other places , such as Hawaii ) do n't experience the influx same amount of deep , sediment - rich ocean water that the West Coast does . It also has more barrier reefs , which help keep sediment - rich water away from the coast . There are also fewer nutrients in the water and less plankton as a result .

message.content: Please explain what is "Functional programming"

response:
Functional programming is a programming paradigm, or a style of building the structure and elements of computer programs, that treats computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions. It is based on the idea of immutability, or the concept that once a piece of data is created, it cannot be changed.



In functional programming, functions are first-class citizens, meaning that they can be passed as arguments to other functions, returned as values from other functions, and assigned to variables. Functions in functional programming do not have side effects, meaning that they do not modify the state of the program or produce any observable interactions with the outside world, such as printing to the console or modifying a file on the filesystem.



Functional programming languages often use recursive functions, which are functions that call themselves, to perform complex computations. They also typically use higher-order functions, which are functions that take other functions as arguments or return functions as output.



Functional programming has its roots in lambda calculus, a formal system developed in the 1930s by mathematician Alonzo Church to study the concept of functions. It has been influential in the design of many programming languages, including Lisp, ML, and Haskell.



Functional programming can be contrasted with imperative programming, which is based on the idea of changing the state of the program through the use of statements that perform actions and modify variables. Imperative programming languages include C, C++, and Java.

message.content: how Tilt Shift photography works . How does it make things look like model landscapes ? Every time I see one I do n't even fathom how it does that Explain like I'm five.

response:
Tilt shift photography is a technique that involves tilting or shifting the lens of a camera in order to change the plane of focus. This can be used to create the illusion that a real-life scene is actually a miniature model.

When you take a normal photograph, the plane of focus is typically parallel to the camera's sensor. This means that objects at different distances from the camera will all be in focus. However, when you tilt or shift the lens, the plane of focus becomes angled, so that only a narrow band of the scene is in focus. This can make the scene look like a miniature model, because the limited depth of field makes it appear as though everything in the photograph is the same size.

Tilt shift photography can be achieved with special lenses that allow the lens to be tilted or shifted, or it can be simulated with image editing software. It is often used to create the illusion of miniature models in landscape and architectural photography, but it can be used in other types of photography as well.

message.content: How do boxers train not to be knocked out ? I have a few theories 1 . A natural physical / physiological resistance 2 . Come back from the brink of being knocked out 3 . Being KO'd frequently builds up resistance Please explain like I'm five.

response:
Boxers train not to be knocked out by doing a variety of things: 
1. Physical training: Boxers work on building strength and endurance in their muscles through weight training, cardio exercises, and sparring (practicing fighting with another boxer). This helps them physically handle the impact of punches and stay on their feet longer during a fight. 
2. Mental training: Boxers also work on their mental toughness by training themselves to stay focused and calm under pressure. They practice techniques like visualization and deep breathing to stay composed and clear-headed, even when they're in the middle of a tough fight. 
3. Techniques to avoid getting hit: Boxers also work on techniques to avoid getting hit, such as dodging, weaving, and footwork. By learning how to move their body effectively and stay out of their opponent's range, they can reduce their chances of getting hit and being knocked out. 
4. Knowing how to take a punch: Finally, boxers learn how to take a punch and minimize the damage it causes. They practice techniques like rolling with the punch and tucking their chin to help absorb the impact and reduce the chances of being knocked out. 
Overall, being a successful boxer requires a combination of physical, mental, and technical skills. By working on all of these areas, boxers can improve their chances of not getting knocked out and having a successful fight.

message.content: Prepaid Rent (Accrual Based Accounting)

response: In accrual-based accounting, prepaid rent refers to the payment of rent in advance for a period of time beyond the current accounting period. When a company pays rent in advance, it is recorded as a prepaid expense on the balance sheet. This means that the full amount of the prepaid rent is not recognized as an expense in the current period, but rather is recognized as an expense in future periods as the company uses the rented property.For example, if a company pays $12,000 in rent for a year in advance, but the accounting period is only for three months, the company would record $3,000 as an expense in the current period (1/4 of the total prepaid rent) and the remaining $9,000 as a prepaid expense on the balance sheet. In the following three months, the company would recognize another $3,000 of the prepaid rent as an expense, and so on until the full amount of the prepaid rent has been recognized as an expense over the course of the year.Prepaid rent is a useful way for companies to manage their cash flow and to ensure that they have the use of the rented property for a specific period of time. It is important for companies to track prepaid expenses and to recognize them as expenses in the appropriate accounting periods to ensure that their financial statements accurately reflect the company's financial performance.

message.content: Please explain what is "Control theory"

response:
Control theory is a branch of engineering that deals with the design, analysis, and implementation of systems that can regulate the behavior of other systems. It is used in a wide variety of fields, including electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, aerospace engineering, and chemical engineering, to name a few.



Control theory is concerned with the development of mathematical models that can describe the behavior of a given system and the design of algorithms that can be used to control the system's behavior. This involves the use of feedback to ensure that the system behaves in a desired way.



Control systems can be classified into two main categories: open-loop systems and closed-loop systems. In an open-loop system, there is no feedback between the system and its environment, so the system's output is determined solely by its inputs. In a closed-loop system, the output of the system is fed back to the system as an input, which allows the system to adjust its behavior in response to changes in the environment.



Control theory is a powerful tool that is used in a wide range of applications, including the control of robots, aircraft, spacecraft, and chemical processes. It is also used in the design of automatic control systems for building heating and cooling systems, power generation plants, and other complex systems.

message.content: Which is the better strategy for buying stocks monthly?

response: There are a few different strategies that you might consider when buying stocks on a monthly basis:Dollar-cost averaging: This involves investing a fixed amount of money in a particular stock or stock portfolio on a regular basis, regardless of the price. This can help to smooth out the impact of market volatility and reduce the risk of buying at the wrong time.Strategic rebalancing: This involves periodically adjusting your portfolio to maintain a target asset allocation. For example, if you have a target allocation of 60% stocks and 40% bonds, and the stock market has had a strong run, you might sell some stocks and buy bonds to bring your portfolio back to your target allocation.Market timing: This involves trying to predict short-term movements in the stock market and buying or selling accordingly. The servers that hold all of the information on the Internet are located in data centers all around the world. When you use the Internet, you access these servers by typing a web address into your computer or smartphone, which sends a request to the server to retrieve the information you want to see. message.content: Am I legally allowed to offset the tax I pay on freelance work? (UK)

response: In the UK, you are generally allowed to offset expenses that you incur in the course of earning your freelance income against your tax liability. This means that you can reduce the amount of tax you owe by the amount you spend on certain expenses related to your freelance work. These expenses must be "wholly and exclusively" for the purpose of your business, and you must be able to provide evidence of the expenses if requested by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).Some examples of expenses that you may be able to offset against your tax liability as a freelancer include:Travel and accommodation expenses related to your business, such as the cost of train or plane tickets, or the cost of staying in a hotel while on businessThe cost of materials, supplies, and equipment used in your business, such as office supplies, software, and hardwareThe cost of training and professional development related to your businessThe cost of hiring subcontractors or other professionals to assist with your businessThe cost of rent or lease payments for business premisesIt's important to keep accurate records of your expenses, as you will need to provide evidence of them to HMRC if requested. You should also be aware that some expenses may be partially deductible (for example, if you use a home office for both personal and business purposes) or may not be deductible at all. You should consult with a tax professional or refer to HMRC's guidance for more information on what expenses you can offset against your tax liability as a freelancer.

message.content: How did freshwater fish species end up across thousands of non - connected lakes across huge regions and sometimes over multiple continents ? I 'm thinking of something like the [ Northern Pike ] ( URL_0 ) , which has a range across North America and Eurasia . Please explain like I'm five.

response:
Great question! Freshwater fish species such as the Northern Pike can end up in non-connected lakes across huge regions and sometimes even on different continents through a process called "dispersal." Dispersal is when an organism (in this case, a fish) moves from one place to another and establishes a new population there. There are a few different ways that freshwater fish species can disperse to new areas: 
1. Natural dispersal: Some fish are good at swimming and can travel long distances to reach new bodies of water. For example, Northern Pike are strong swimmers and can travel downstream to reach new lakes or rivers. 
2. Human-aided dispersal: Humans can also play a role in the dispersal of fish species. For example, people may introduce a new species of fish into a body of water for recreational fishing, or they may accidentally release a fish into a new area while transporting it for some other reason. 
3. Historical dispersal: In some cases, fish species may have dispersed to new areas in the past, and then become established there. For example, during the last ice age, many parts of the world were covered in ice, and some fish species may have survived in isolated pockets of water. When the ice melted, these fish were able to spread out and establish populations in new areas. 
Overall, the process of dispersal helps to explain how freshwater fish species like the Northern Pike can end up in non-connected lakes across huge regions and even on different continents.

message.content: Why are processed carbs like white bread and white rice considered so bad for you ? And why the emphasis on ' whole grains ' instead ? What 's the difference ? Explain like I'm five.

response:
Processed carbs like white bread and white rice are considered bad for you because they have been stripped of their outer layer, which contains most of the nutrients. When a grain of rice or wheat is harvested, it has a tough outer layer called the husk. To make white rice or white bread, the husk is removed and the grain is ground up into a fine powder. This makes the resulting product softer and easier to chew, but it also removes many of the nutrients that are found in the husk.

Whole grains, on the other hand, are grains that have not had the husk removed. They are left intact, which means that they contain all of the nutrients that are found in the husk. This makes whole grains a much healthier choice than processed carbs like white bread and white rice, because they contain more fiber, vitamins, and minerals.

So, to sum it up: processed carbs like white bread and white rice are bad for you because they have had most of their nutrients removed, while whole grains are good for you because they contain all of their nutrients.
